III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A resides in Adrian Group Home. Staff 1 is a staff member
at the group home. On 07/20/2025, Staff 1 slapped Youth A on
her left cheek. There is a small scratch on Youth A's left cheek. It
is unknown if it is from being slapped by Staff 1.
Second allegation involving Staff 1: Youth B resides at Adrian
Group Home. Staff 1 is a previous staff member at the home.
Last night, Youth B was escalated. Staff 1 lost her cool, resulting
in her shoving and slapping Youth B in the face. Youth B does not
have any visible injuries, marks or bruises. Staff 1 was sent home
and later resigned from the job.
Investigation Administrator 2 was interviewed via phone on 7/21/2025. He
reported Youth A had become aggressive with other youth and
staff when Staff 1 lost her composure and struck Youth A. He had
no further information to add about the allegations with the
exception that when he arrived at the facility 15 minutes after
being informed by Staff 2 of the incident, Staff 1 handed him her
keys and resigned from employment. He also reported Staff 3 is a
possible witness but the other staff working at the time were busy
with other youth when the incident occurred. Administrator 2 was
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility with MDHHS
Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. He reported arriving at the facility after
being informed by Staff 2 of the incident involving Staff 1 slapping
Youth A. Upon arriving at the facility, he found Staff 1 in the
bathroom crying and Staff 1 informed Administrator 2 that she
slapped Youth A because she was feeling overwhelmed. He
reported being informed by Staff 1 that Youth A was slapping and
hitting Staff 1 so Staff 1 slapped Youth A and then slapped Youth
B. Administrator 2 reported Staff 1 left the facility to go home and
returned with her keys at which time she resigned her position at
2

the facility. He reported having an exit meeting with Staff 1 and
has no concerns about Staff 1 being rehired at the facility because
a plan of no rehire will be placed in her HR file. Administrator 2
reported Staff 1 was hired approximately 90 days ago because
she was ready for her 90-day evaluation in a few days. He
reported Staff 1 had no disciplinary action documented in her
personnel file. Administrator 2 reported there is camera footage,
but the angle is poor, but there is also Staff 4 who may have
witnessed some of the events along with Staff 3.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
with MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. She reported being
debriefed on Monday (July 21. 2025) about the incident and will
provide the incident reports and HR file information. She reported
being told by staff present at the time that Staff 1 tends to be
ridged and she has addressed appropriate language with all staff.
She reported planning on speaking to Staff 1 during the upcoming
90-day evaluation that Staff 1 needs to work on building rapport
with the youth. Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 has no disciplinary
action in her HR file and was never late nor never called off a shift.
She reported Staff 1 had been hurt a couple of times by youth
hitting and throwing things at Staff 1. Staff 1 was hit in the eye
when a youth threw something at Staff 1.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. He reported working at the time
of the incident and being a witness to Staff 1 slapping Youth B on
Youth B’s left facial cheek. He reported Staff 1 informed him she
slapped Youth A but never observed this action himself, but did
witness Staff 1 hit Youth B. He described what he witnessed in
regard to Youth B being slapped. “I was walking towards [Youth B]
from [Youth B’s] left side and [Youth B] was sitting on the floor
when [Staff 1] approached [Youth B] and hit him on his left facial
cheek with her hand”. Staff 4 didn’t recall which hand Staff 1 used
but also described that Youth B and Youth C were “going at each
other” by throwing things at each other. He reported Youth B’s
cheek didn’t turn red and it appeared Youth B was more surprised
than upset. Staff 4 reported trying to call Administrator 2 but was
unable to connect but did believe Staff 2 had called Administrator
2 earlier about Staff 1 slapping Youth A. He reported walking with
Youth A down the road where they met Administrator 2 coming to
the facility. At this time, the youth in the program were doing well,
and everyone had settled down because Staff 1 had removed
herself from the area. Staff 4 was asked about informing a
supervisor and he reported never taking that action with Staff 1,
believing some other staff would inform a supervisor. He reported
3

never witnessing Staff 1 engage in this time of behavior before.
He reported the staff present on shift at the time of the incident
were Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and himself (Staff 4).
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. Youth B reported not knowing
what happened between Youth A and Staff 1 but believes Staff 1
slapped Youth A harder than Staff 1 slapped Youth B. Youth B
reported the youth were in a “crisis” as evidenced by Youth A
attacking Staff 1. Youth B described a “crisis” as when youth are
dysregulated. Youth B reported Staff 1 has a history of threatening
to slap youth if they hit her. Youth B reported observing a red
mark on Youth A’s face and reported throwing a glass at Staff 1
because Staff 1 slapped Youth A but missing with the glass which
“almost hit her heart”. Youth B reported Staff 1 slapped him (Youth
B) before Staff 1 pinned Youth B on the couch. Youth B reported
the slap left no marks on Youth B’s left facial cheek and Youth B’s
face didn’t hurt. Youth B reported a belief that all staff witnessed
Youth A being slapped by Staff 1. Youth B was asked about
feeling safe and reported with the exception of Youth C messing
with others, Youth B felt safe.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. Youth C reported not being
present during the two incidents with Staff 1, Youth A, and Youth
B. Youth C reported being informed of the incidents by other
youth. Youth C reported seeing Staff 1 push Youth B against the
wall the same day but never witnessed Staff 1 slap Youth B.
Youth C reported if witnessing a staff being aggressive with a
youth, Youth C would report this staff to Administrator 2 or a team
leader. Youth C reported feeling safe at the facility.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. She reported working very little
with Staff 1 but did report Staff 1 would engage in horseplay with
the youth by letting the youth place their hands on Staff 1 but
nothing inappropriate. She reported being told by Youth B during
one shift a few weeks ago that Youth B was fearful of Staff 1, so
Staff 5 stayed beyond her normal working hours to provide
support for Youth B since she was identified as Youth B’s safe
person.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone with MDHHS Worker 1 on
8/5/2025. She reported the incident began after staff took the
youth to a local swimming pool and were riding back to the facility.
Staff 1 was with Staff 2 when Youth B and Youth C began
4

screaming and throwing items at each other. Once back at the
facility, Youth B continued to be “amped up” and began attacking
Staff 1. Staff 1 reported standing in a corner in the milieu trying to
protect herself while Youth B was pushing and hitting Staff 1. Staff
1 stated, “I kept trying to get away from [Youth B], but I was
getting my butt kicked the whole time”. Staff 1 reported Youth A
then began to attack Staff 1 and both Youth A and Youth B were
swinging, hitting and pushing Staff 1 from different sides. Staff 1
reported as she was trying to block a hit from Youth A in front of
her, Youth B pushed Staff 1 causing Staff 1’s hand to make
contact with Youth A’s face. Staff 1 reported not realizing she had
made contact with Youth A when another Youth (unable to recall
who) said Staff 1 had hit Youth A. Staff 1 did not see any mark on
Youth A's face, but Youth A didn’t stop attacking Staff 1. Staff 1
reported saying “I’m done because no staff are backing me up”.
Because other Staff (Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4) did not step in to
help, Staff 1 reported leaving the situation. Staff 1 reported yelling
“I’m done” and walked away. Regarding the allegations of hitting
Youth B, Staff 1 reported Youth B was sitting on the floor throwing
things and yelling. Staff 1 reported putting her hand against Youth
B’s cheek and telling Youth B to “chill”. She denied anything more
than this (placing hand on face) occurred with Youth B. She
reported Youth B said, “you can’t slap me” and telling Youth B that
Staff 1 had only put her hand on his face. At that time, Youth B
picked up broken glass (Youth A had broken glass earlier) and
threw it at Staff 1 while yelling “die bitch die”. Staff 1 reported
pushing Youth B onto the couch in the milieu after Youth B threw
glass at her. She described this action as pushing Youth B from
the front and Youth B landing in a seated position. She minimized
this action by stating “basically I helped Youth B have a seat”. She
denied holding Youth B down on the couch but did report getting
into Youth B’s face and telling Youth B that Staff 1 was done. Staff
1 denied pushing Youth B against the wall as was seen in the
video footage because “Youth B was at my back”. Staff 1 was
asked about threatening youth and she denied any threats other
than to tell youth if they hit Staff 1, she will call the police and did
call the police the day Staff 1 was hit with a box and had a cut
eye. Staff 1 then began to recall past events in which she suffered
injury. Staff 1 reported displacing ribs within the first 30-days of
employment and being told to “suck it up” when seeking support
from administration. She reported telling Administrator 2 that she
was “done” and went home to get her employment items and
came back and gave it to Administrator 2.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 8/11/2025. She reported being present during the two incidents
5

that are described in the allegations with Youth A and Youth B.
She reported Staff 1 hit Youth A on the face on Youth A’s cheek,
leaving a red mark and Staff 1 also hit Youth B on the face after
pinning Youth B against a wall. Staff 3 reported the incidents
began after the youth in the program returned from a local
swimming pool and Youth B entered the building upset. Youth B
had been in an argument as described by Staff 1 with Youth C
and this argument escalated once in the building and after Youth
C broke a Lego figure of Youth B. Staff 3 reported Youth A
became triggered by Youth B and Youth A began attacking Staff 1
by hitting and slapping Staff 1. Staff 3 reported trying to step in
and stop Youth A from hitting Staff 1 but at this time Youth B
began to hit Staff 1. Youth B was hitting Staff 1 from the front of
Staff 1 while Youth A was hitting Staff 1 from the backside. After
slapping Youth A, which Staff 3 believes was an accident by Staff
1, Staff 1 turned to Youth B and pinned Youth B to the wall trying
to get Youth B to stop hitting Staff 1. Staff 3 reported telling Staff 1
that Staff 1 could not do a restraint in that way and needed to let
Youth B go. When Staff 1 let Youth B go, Youth B hit Staff 1 and
Staff 3 reported Staff 1 said “if you hit me, I will hit you” and hit
Youth B in his right facial cheek. Staff 3 believes the hit on Youth
B was intentional because of what Staff 1 said right before hitting
Youth B.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 8/11/2025. She reported working at the facility the day and
time of the incidents outlined in the allegations. She reported
being in the bathroom and not witnessing some of the allegations.
She reported there was a lot of chaos going on with the youths
and Youth B was in crisis. She reported Youth A will get
dysregulated when hearing loud noises and because of Youth B
acting out, Youth A began to act out. She reported not witnessing
Staff 1 hit either youth (Youth A or Youth B) but did witness Staff 1
“go after” Youth B after Youth B threw glass at Staff 1. She denied
observing any marks on either youth (Youth A or Youth B). Staff 2
reported feeling supported by administration and going over
behavior management skills (restraint training) weekly.
Documents Reviewed:
Interview with Youth A completed by MDHHS Worker 2 on
07/21/25 at 11:36am:
MDHHS Worker 2 asked to speak with Youth A privately. MDHHS
Worker 2 introduced self to Youth A. She was not able to be
forensically interviewed due to cognitive delays. She was not able
to answer open-ended questions. She either said no or mumbles
6

some words that were not intelligible. MDHHS Worker 2 asked
how things were at the home. She said good. When asked how
they were good, she stared at MDHHS Worker 2. She was asked
what her favorite thing to do was and she replied to play. She was
asked who her favorite staff was, and she said Staff 5. She was
then asked if there was a staff that she did not like. She said no.
MDHHS Worker 2 asked if anyone has hurt her. She shook her
head no. She was asked if anyone had hit or slapped her. She
shook her head no. MDHHS Worker 2 asked who Staff 1 was and
Youth A said, "I don't know." MDHHS Worker 2 asked about the
scratch on her chin. She said, "Staff 1 did it." MDHHS Worker 2
asked how she did it. Youth A moved her hand in a slapping
motion. She was asked if it hurt and she said yes. Youth A was
observed to have a small scratch on the left side of her chin. It
was about an inch long. A picture was taken. Youth A was
observed to have no other visible injuries or bruises.
Genacross Lutheran Services Behavior Management
policy/procedure dated 5/20/25. This document outlines the
behavior interventions that are approved to use in efforts to assist
with behavior management. This document outlines the behavior
management techniques that are approved such as redirection,
modeling, changing the environment, and prompting.
Genacross Lutheran Services Disciplinary policy/procedure
dated 4/24/24. This document outlines those actions that are
prohibited by staff when working with the youth.
Policy:
1. Any cruel and unusual punishments/practices are prohibited
including, but not limited to:
a. Physical punishment such as spanking, punching, paddling,
shaking, biting, spitting, hair pulling, pinching, pushing, physical
hitting inflicted in any manner upon the body or roughly
handling a child.
b. Physically strenuous work or exercises, when used as a
means of punishment, consequence or discipline.
c. Forcing a child to maintain an uncomfortable position, or to
continuously repeat physical movements when used as a
means of punishment, consequence or discipline.
d. Group punishments for the behavior of an individual. A group
activity shall not be cancelled for the entire group, prior to the
activity, due to the behavior of one or more individuals.
7

e. Verbal abuse, including swearing, directed at a child or
derogatory remarks about a child's family, race, gender identity,
sexual orientation, disability, religion, or cultural background or
threats of physical violence against the child or removal of the
child from the facility.
f. Denial of social or recreational activities for more than five
consecutive days without prior written approval of the facility
administrator or designee and a certified or licensed
practitioner of behavioral science.
g. The denial of social, mental health or casework services,
medical treatment, educational services or access to their
guardian ad litem or attorney, probation officer, court appointed
special advocate, placement worker or caseworker.
h. The deprivation of any meal or snack. Food cannot be used
as a punishment. All youth will be offered the same or similar
snack and must be aligned with dietary guidelines.
i. The use or denial of any medication as a punishment or
discipline.
j. The denial of visitation or communication rights with a child's
family as a means of punishment or discipline.
k. The denial of sleep.
l. The denial of shelter, clothing, bedding, or restroom facilities.
m. The use of physical restraint as a means of punishment or
discipline.
n. Organized social ostracism such as codes of silence.
o. The use of chemical restraint.
p. The use of mechanical restraint.
q. Isolation in a locked or unlocked room used as punishment.
s. The use of prone restraints is prohibited. Prone restraint is
defined as all items or measures used to limit or control the
movement or normal functioning of any portion, or all, of an
individual's body while the individual is in a face-down position
for an extended period of time. Prone restraint includes
physical or mechanical restraint.
t. Time out exceeding one minute for each year of the child's
age, unless approval is granted by a certified or licensed
practitioner of behavioral science and documented in the child's
service plan.
8

u. Punishment for actions over which the child has no control
such as bedwetting, enuresis, encopresis or incidents that
occur in the course of toilet training activities.
2. Discipline shall be administered only by persons who are
administrators or employees with direct care responsibilities of the
residential facility.
3. Agency employees, contract staff, student interns and volunteers
shall not engage in any act of omission or commission which results
in the death, injury, illness, abuse, neglect, or exploitation of any
child.
Genacross Lutheran Services Incident Report for Youth A
dated 7/20/25 @ 4:45 pm. This document outlines the incident
with Youth A in the allegations. It is labeled as agitation or
aggression and allegations. The incident is described as Youth A
becoming agitated and physically assaulting another youth
(unidentified but believe it was Youth B) by punching the youth.
Staff 1 is documented as attempting to redirect Youth A by
creating space between Youth A and the other youth. This
resulted in Youth A assaulting Staff 1 by hitting and slapping Staff
1 and Staff 1 slapping Youth A on the right cheek. It is also
documented that Staff 3 intervened by creating space between
Youth A and Staff 1 before Staff 1 left and went into the staff
office. Youth A went for a walk down the street with Staff 4 as a
type of de-escalation. Youth A is documented as sharing Youth A
was triggered from all the loud noises in the house. Staff involved
are documented as Staff 1, Staff 3, and Staff 4.
Genacross Lutheran Services Incident Report for Youth B
dated 7/20/25 @ 12:20 pm. This document labels this incident as
“CIR and other” and the summary involves Administrator 1 and
Administrator 2 as debriefing the incident in which Staff 1 is
alleged to have shoved and slapped Youth B. It is documented
that Administrator 2 called MDHHS about the incident.
Genacross Lutheran Services Incident Report for Youth B
dated 7/20/25 @ 4:45 pm. This document outlines the incident
alleged in the second set of allegations and is identified as
“Personal safety techniques”. It is documented that Youth B and
Youth C were becoming aggressive towards each other and after
Youth C threw Youth B’s Legos on the floor and walked away,
Youth B continued to yell at staff. Youth B used the “n” word which
upset another youth who then “vaulted after Youth B and began to
hit and kick Youth B. Once Youth B and the other youth
(unidentified youth in this report but believe it was Youth C) were
9

separated, Youth B began to become aggressive towards staff
and staff’s attempts to de-escalate Youth B were “futile”. Staff
involved were identified as Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3.
Video Review:
This video footage dated 7/20/25 is a view of the milieu with a
forward view of the sliding door. Staff 4 is observed walking
across this area towards Youth B who appears to be standing
behind a small table. Staff 4 walks past Youth B and it appears
Staff 1 enters from the left of Youth B and appears to strike Youth
B in the face area with her hand while pushing Youth B against
the wall. They then separate and only Youth B is seen standing
against the wall.
This video footage dated 7/20/25 is a view of the hallway leading
into the milieu. The only view of what is believed to be Staff 1 and
Youth A is below their waists. It one point in the video appears
they are close together then what is believed to be Youth A’s legs
appears to back away from the legs of Staff 1. There is no hitting
in the view.
HR file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Documentation indicates Staff
1 was hired on 4/28/25 and there is no disciplinary action
documented in the file with the exception of the termination
information for this incident. Staff 1 was also up to date on her
required trainings and orientation.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility a single-
story building in good repair. The facility is also very well furnished
in all aspects. The bedroom were appropriately furnished and
maintained like the rest of the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as evidenced by interviews
with staff, youth, documents and video recording. Evidence does
support the allegations that Staff 1 slapped Youth A and Youth B
along with pushing Youth B on to a couch while saying derogatory
statements to Youth B.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding staff’s interactions
with the youth in the program and other staff. Staff should be
aware of the emotional state of each youth in their care along with
10

their coworkers during the shift. Staff, especially the
lead/supervisor staff should understand if a line staff is
experiencing any type of personal stressors, so they don’t’
increase the changes of becoming dysregulated while working
with difficult youth in the program. Staff must understand the role
of a healing agent and guard against their own issues creating
difficulty in dealing with youth in the program.
Technical assistance was offered regarding staff checking in at
the beginning of the shift with the lead/supervisor staff to ensure
they are emotionally ready to deal with the stressors of working
with youth in the program. Staff should also understand the
importance of holding each other accountable to provide the art of
best practice when dealing with damaged youth.
Technical assistance was offered regarding the lack of the
following prohibit forms of intervention not documented in the
facility’s discipline policy. This involves the following prohibited
forms of discipline.
• The use of pepper spray, tear gas, and mace.
• Striking, throwing, kicking and pulling,
• Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
• Peer-on-peer discipline.
• Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following: Shelter,
clothing, medical care, or essential personal needs,
including culturally specific items.
• Any actions that inhibit a youth’s ability to achieve
permanency.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,

11

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 1 is alleged to have cursed at Youth B.
Investigation Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. Staff 4 was asked about working
with Staff 1 and he reported Staff 1’s interactions with the youth
“were alright but not the best.”. He reported Staff 1 would tell the
youth if they hit her, she will slap the youth. Staff 4 reported, telling
Staff 1 she should not speak to any youth in that manner.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. Youth B reported Staff 1 has a
history of threatening to slap youth if they hit her.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 7/23/2025. Youth C reported Staff 1 had a
history of cursing at youth often and calling youth curse names
(pricks, assholes, or whatnots). Youth C reported the other staff
(no specific example) would tell Staff 1 to not curse at or around
youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 8/5/2025. She reported not remembering all she said to Youth
B but then remembered she told Youth B that Youth B will never
get adopted because “Youth B is a psychopath”. Staff 1 attempted
to justify her statement by reporting Youth B was talking about her
family, thus allowing Staff 1 to talk about Youth B’s family. Staff 1
never said she threatened to hit Youth A and never cursed at
Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 8/11/2025. When Staff 1 let Youth B go, Youth B hit Staff 1 and
Staff 3 reported Staff 1 said “if you hit me, I will hit you” and hit
Youth B in his right facial cheek.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 8/11/2025. She reported Staff 1 was chasing Youth B around
the room yelling “I have a family” before witnessing Staff 1 push
Youth B into a couch. Staff 2 was asked about Staff 1’s
interactions with the youth and reported Staff 1 would swear at
youth when the youth throw something at Staff 1. Staff 2 reported
confronting Staff 1 about swearing at the youth and Staff 1 would
respond with “well they are swearing at me and harming me, can’t
punish them but they need to learn a lesson”. Staff 2 described
Staff 1 as being “like a drill sergeant”.
12

Documents Reviewed:
Genacross Lutheran Services Disciplinary policy/procedure
dated 4/24/24. This document outlines those actions that are
prohibited by staff when working with the youth. Verbal abuse
such as swearing, derogatory remarks about or to a youth or
youth’s family are also prohibited.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as evidenced by interviews
with staff, youth, documents and video recording. Evidence does
support the allegations that Staff 1 said derogatory statements to
Youth B. This evidence is found in Staff 1’s own statements and
the statements of other staff and Youth B.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding developing a system
during the hiring process to ensure the facility understands the
potential new staff’s ability to handle stressful situations in a calm
and professional manner. This can be done in part by role-playing
different types of situations to evaluate how the staff would handle
the situation.
Technical assistance was offered regarding the evaluation
process of a new employee. It was suggested Administration
receive feedback from all the peers of the staff to be evaluated so
they have a well-rounded view of the staff rather than just relying
on a supervisor who has limited contact with the staff.
Conclusion Violation Established
13

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: On July 20, 2025, Staff 1 at Adrian Group Home, after youth became dysregulated and aggressive, struck Youth A in the face (leaving a small scratch) and later slapped and pushed Youth B, also making derogatory verbal threats. The investigation substantiated these physical and verbal abuses, which violate policies prohibiting physical punishment and verbal abuse. The primary culpability lies with Staff 1 for her abusive actions, though the facility's administration is also accountable for inadequate oversight and a recent prior similar violation.
